text: Hi there! I am interested in moving from your traditional guide/ebook/whitepaper content and creating more checklists and templates, etc. I'm not sure exactly where to start. Some of the stuff we've created in the past I don't think has actually been used. Does anyone have advice on how to learn how to do this, how to make sure it's what your audience wants and will use, and suggested formats? (I'm thinking something like Google docs/Google sheets since you can make a copy so easily to use yourself.)

text: I generally share a creative brief for each new project for a freelancer (they get less detailed as the freelancer gets more familiar) that includes the keywords, audiences, background for the project, goals, purpose,  length, timeline, expected tone, etc. But in addition, I've put together a "new writer packet" for all new freelancers. It includes persona information, product brochures for our main products, our brand voice, and our style guide. Like Kane said I also make sure they're fine w/ the legal/payment side of things too, like if you pay on net 15 terms and if they have any issues with the contract, etc.

elements.text: I generally share a creative brief for each new project for a freelancer (they get less detailed as the freelancer gets more familiar) that includes the keywords, audiences, background for the project, goals, purpose,  length, timeline, expected tone, etc. But in addition, I've put together a "new writer packet" for all new freelancers. It includes persona information, product brochures for our main products, our brand voice, and our style guide. Like Kane said I also make sure they're fine w/ the legal/payment side of things too, like if you pay on net 15 terms and if they have any issues with the contract, etc.

text: <@U01HEQWRG0G> Love everything <@U01AHL8AGBB> shared! I guess it depends on what kind of community you're talking about - whether you mean a community of fans (your audience) or an actual community, more what Jordy was talking about. I think Gong is a good example of a brand who is growing the first type of community (the audience) through all their social media and content marketing and branding efforts. But if you're talking about the second, a branded online community that you build and invite customers or prospects or industry folks to join (like Sephora's... Gain Grow Retain's... etc) then there's definitely a science and process. I think <@UJG9WTEKG> could speak to this, he's done such a nice job of building this Slack community! I'm not an expert in this but rub shoulders w/ a lot of community builders because that's what my company does. I'd recommend you follow Georgina Cannie Donahue, Chris Detzel, Carrie Melissa Jones, Jay Nathan and Jeff Breunsbach on LinkedIn to get those real gems of wisdom :slightly_smiling_face: We also have a lot of pieces on our blog about this, if helpful: this one with Georgina Donahue <https://www.higherlogic.com/blog/online-communities-of-practice-pragmatic-institute/> and this one with Jay Nathan <https://www.higherlogic.com/blog/gain-grow-retain-customer-success-community/>

attachments.title: Online Communities of Practice: A How-to Guide - Higher Logic
attachments.text: Can’t-miss advice from Georgina Donahue, Director of Community at the Pragmatic Institute on how to build an online community of practice.
attachments.fallback: Higher Logic: Online Communities of Practice: A How-to Guide - Higher Logic

attachments.title: Gain Grow Retain's Story: A Customer Success Community - Higher Logic
attachments.text: Find out how Gain Grow Retain, the world's fastest-growing customer success community, got its start and continues to engage customer success leaders.
attachments.fallback: Higher Logic: Gain Grow Retain's Story: A Customer Success Community - Higher Logic

text: Although you're looking for full-time writers I think you could definitely use Grow & Convert's framework for testing freelancers. They suggest having them pitch blog titles that they think would fit with your blog and then if you like, you pick one, if you use it, you pay them, if you don't use it, you dont pay them. You might have to figure out the incentive thing differently since you're potentially hiring them but i think their approach can still work. <https://growandconvert.com/hire-writers/> <@U01G7PRL3HQ>

attachments.title: How to Hire Freelance Blog Writers (w/ Templates and Examples)
attachments.text: We share our exact step-by-step process to find and hire blog writers. Build teams of high quality blog writers in multiple industries. Steal our process.
attachments.fallback: Grow and Convert: How to Hire Freelance Blog Writers (w/ Templates and Examples)

text: I lean toward yes <@UJJFDTN8G> primarily because of google's e-a-t, _and_ i want readers to trust what we're writing. I've intentionally stopped putting myself as the author (it was our norm before!) and work with internal SMEs at my company to have them review and "author" content. So a lot of the time the info comes from them or another SME who I interview, then I / freelancer will write it up, they review it, and I publish under their name. It's more work but I think it makes for better content that's not mirage content and more trusted because it's coming from an expert and not someone who writes and may not know about the subject.

It's more work but I think it makes for better content that's not mirage content and more trusted because it's coming from an expert and not someone who writes and may not know about the subject.

text:
I think of workbooks, checklists, tipsheets, and templates as ancillary to ebooks, guides, and whitepapers.

Let's say you're publishing a guide to effective online community management strategy. The content will be a mix of strategic insight and light tactical actions for the reader to take. Then repurpose those tactical actions and expand on them to create a checklist or workbook that prescribes step-by-step instructions and exercises to implement the strategic ideas from the guide.

Business books have used this tactic for ages. More recently, business book authors have leveraged ancillary material to capture reader emails since marketplaces like Amazon own the customer relationship.

elements.text:

Then repurpose those tactical actions and expand on them to create a checklist or workbook that prescribes step-by-step instructions and exercises to implement the strategic ideas from the guide.

Business books have used this tactic for ages. More recently, business book authors have leveraged ancillary material to capture reader emails since marketplaces like Amazon own the customer relationship.

text:
<@UMQASRN1W> we do quite a few worksheets, checklists, etc. Once we increased volume, our design team helped us create a branded Google Doc template with common elements (e.g. text blocks, a table with check boxes, CTA/about section, etc) and did a training on Adobe for creating fillable PDFs. Content creators use the Docs template and design does a quick review at the end before they make it a PDF.

Agree with <@UUH2EB134> that the best downloads build off a successful piece of content and walk people through how to implement recommendations themselves. In the pre-COVID days we’d also sometimes create resource sheets that someone might print out and put in their office (e.g. best times to post, hashtag holidays - our focus is social media) but most folks don’t have printers at home now!
